column1: Winona is a city in and the county seat of Winona County
column2: in the state of Minnesota.  Located in picturesque bluff country on the Mississippi River
column3: its most noticeable physical landmark is Sugar Loaf. The city is named after legendary figure Winona
column4: said to have been the first-born daughter of Chief Wapasha (Wabasha) III. The total population of the city was 27
column5: 592 at the time of the 2010 census.

column1: The city of Winona began on the site of a Native American village named Keoxa.  The seat of the Wapasha dynasty
column2: Keoxa was home to a Mdewakanton band of the eastern Sioux.

column1: Non-Native Americans settled the area in 1851 and laid out the town into lots in 1852 and 1853.  The original settlers were Yankee immigrants from New England.   The population increased from 815 in December
column5: 1856.  In 1856 German immigrants arrived as well.  The Germans and the Yankees worked together planting trees and building businesses based on lumber
column9: 000 Poles and closely related Kashubians emigrated to Winona
column10: making up one quarter of the population. Since 80% of them were Kashubians
column11: Winona became known as the "Kashubian Capital of America". As a result of the influx of Polish Catholic immigrants
column12: the Church of St. Stanislaus (now Basilica of St. Stanislaus Kostka) was built. For a time
column13: Winona had more millionaires than any other city of its size in the United States.The railroad and steamboat transportation industries helped Winona grow into a small city that diversified into wheat milling
column16: 300 steamboats stopped at Winona. The Winona and St. Peter Railroad first segment of 11 miles (18 km) from Winona to Stockton
column17: Minnesota was completed by the end of 1862. Winona then had the second operational railroad in Minnesota
column18: after the St. Paul and Pacific Line from Saint Paul to St. Anthony Falls. In December 1870
column19: the Mississippi River was bridged at Winona by the Winona Rail Bridge. In 1892
column20: a wagon toll-bridge over the Mississippi
column22: was completed and remained in service until the opening of the Main Channel Bridge in 1942.

column1: Winona has two historic districts listed on the National Register of Historic Places that combine into a single local historic district administered by the city's Heritage Preservation Commission.
A bandshell was completed in 1924 for outdoor musical performances and events. The Winona Municipal Bands holds concerts there during the summer.
According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 24.13 square miles (62.50 km2); 18.84 square miles (48.80 km2) is land and 5.29 square miles (13.70 km2) is water. Lock and Dam 5A spans the Mississippi River in Winona. The highway bridge connecting Winona to the Wisconsin side of the river is at approximately River Mile 726 (USACE map 31).

column1: Winona was once served by four railroads; Milwaukee Road (CMStP&P)
column3: Chicago Great Western (CGW) and Green Bay & Western (GB&W)
column4: with the Burlington Route (CB&Q) trains stopping at a station across the river in Wisconsin. Only the former Milwaukee Road station remains and is now served by Amtrak's Empire Builder daily in each direction between Chicago and Seattle and Portland. column1: Sugar Loaf is river bluff topped by a distinctive rock pinnacle
column2: which was left after quarrying activity in the 19th century.  It is located at the junction of Highway 61 and Highway 43/Mankato Avenue.

column1: Basilica of Saint Stanislaus Kostka is a historic Catholic church built in 1895 in the Polish Cathedral Style.
Lake Winona is separated from the Mississippi River by downtown Winona. It is surrounded by a park
column2: which contains the Winona Lake Park Bandshell and a recreation center.

column1: Garvin Heights City Park is an overlook of the Mississippi River that is used to view a panorama of the city and surrounding area.
